channel.title: Youtube downloading & legality
channel.description:
I've asked a few people about this and some say its legal and some say it's not.
Obviously the main fact here is that when you visit youtube, the video is being downloaded into your cache. So in theory, downloading the video from the exact same source but storing it in a file you wish to access later is just the same.
However, there is a difference between going on youtube to watch a video and having it innocently stored in your cache than downloading a video specifically so you can save it, convert it to an MP3 and essentially listen to free music.
I can make an application that does all the stuff mentioned above just by inputting a song name, while if I did the same thing on an MP3 sharing site it'd be illegal. It just doesn't feel right getting free music legally. Or maybe I'm just being a faggot.

item.title: Youtube downloading & legality
item.dc:creator: @TabbyKiller TabbyKiller
item.description:
@TabbyKiller wrote:

I had this in mind a while back but wanted to wait until I learned programming.

item.title: Youtube downloading & legality
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:5, topic:326377”][quote author=inertia link=topic=422788.msg3103606#msg3103606 date=1263922668]
That looks promising, but what can the actual record companies do? Do they essentially agree that their music can be downloaded when they upload it to youtube? (or in the case that some random guy uploads their songs, it’s his fault not mine)
[/quote]

Officially you’re not allowed to upload copyrighted material to YouTube. They won’t prosecute you for listening to that.[/quote]If you’re familiar with “AVC” or “AAC”, it has a feature that extracts the video and converts in into a playable form whether it be in video or audio format. So, theoretically, if the record company or any owner of the music willfully uploads their content onto youtube, is it illegal to use AVC or AAC do download the file?

Read full topic

item.title: Youtube downloading & legality
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:19, topic:326377”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=422788.msg3105230#msg3105230 date=1264089495]
Right. It’s impossible to create something and NOT have it copyrighted.
[/quote]

My bad, I misunderstood a description of copyright.

However, while registration isn’t needed to exercise copyright, in jurisdictions where the laws provide for registration, it serves as prima facie evidence of a valid copyright and enables the copyright holder to seek statutory damages and attorney’s fee

So, what I now mean is: You are not allowed to upload copyrighted material to YouTube, unless it’s your own. I thought that you had to apply for it in all cases. You can, but you don’t have to.[/quote]

If people are allowed to upload their own copyrighted material without it affecting their copyright, then surely it’s illegal for others to copy it? Or is it legal to use copyrighted stuff for personal use?

Read full topic

item.title: Youtube downloading & legality

item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Mopman:

Right. It’s impossible to create something and NOT have it copyrighted.

My bad, I misunderstood a description of copyright.

However, while registration isn't needed to exercise copyright, in jurisdictions where the laws provide for registration, it serves as prima facie evidence of a valid copyright and enables the copyright holder to seek statutory damages and attorney's fee

So, what I now mean is: You are not allowed to upload copyrighted material to YouTube, unless it’s your own. I thought that you had to apply for it in all cases. You can, but you don’t have to.

Read full topic

item.title: Youtube downloading & legality
item.dc:creator: @teh_spede Teh Spede
item.description:
@teh_spede wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:16, topic:326377”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=422788.msg3104395#msg3104395 date=1264017706]

Officially you’re not allowed to upload copyrighted material to YouTube. They won’t prosecute you for listening to that.

Of course you can, if you own the copyright. Otherwise, at least in the USA, nobody could ever upload anything.

I hope you understand what I mean.

apparently not
[/quote]

I doubt many members here have any officially copyrighted material.[/quote]Everything you make yourself is immediately copyrighted?

item.title: Youtube downloading & legality
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:3, topic:326377”][quote]11. YouTube content on the Website
11.1 With the exception of User Submissions, all other content on the Website including, without limitation, the text, software, scripts, graphics, photos, sounds, music, videos and interactive features on the Website b[/b] is either owned by or licensed to YouTube, and is subject to copyright, trade mark rights, and other intellectual property rights of YouTube or YouTube’s licensors. Any third party trade or service marks present on the YouTube Content are trade or service marks of their respective owners.

11.2 YouTube Content may not be downloaded, copied, reproduced, distributed, transmitted, broadcast, displayed, sold, licensed, or otherwise exploited for any other purpose whatsoever without the prior written consent of YouTube, or YouTube’s licensors. YouTube reserves all rights not expressly granted in and to the YouTube Content.[/quote]

You are allowed to download everything, except YouTube Content. The definition of YouTube Content is underlined in the text above.[/quote]

That looks promising, but what can the actual record companies do? Do they essentially agree that their music can be downloaded when they upload it to youtube? (or in the case that some random guy uploads their songs, it’s his fault not mine)

Read full topic

item.title: Youtube downloading & legality
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

11. YouTube content on the Website 11.1 [b]With the exception of User Submissions,[/b] [u]all other content on the Website including, without limitation, the text, software, scripts, graphics, photos, sounds, music, videos and interactive features on the Website[/u] [b](the "YouTube Content")[/b] is either owned by or licensed to YouTube, and is subject to copyright, trade mark rights, and other intellectual property rights of YouTube or YouTube's licensors. Any third party trade or service marks present on the YouTube Content are trade or service marks of their respective owners.

11.2 YouTube Content may not be downloaded, copied, reproduced, distributed, transmitted, broadcast, displayed, sold, licensed, or otherwise exploited for any other purpose whatsoever without the prior written consent of YouTube, or YouTube’s licensors. YouTube reserves all rights not expressly granted in and to the YouTube Content.

You are allowed to download everything, except YouTube Content. The definition of YouTube Content is underlined in the text above.

Read full topic

item.title: Youtube downloading & legality
item.dc:creator: @akl akl
item.description:
@akl wrote:

My dad needed an app for his iPhone where he could download, but it needed to be jailbroken or unlocked or something to download Cydia.

I believe Apple has such apps in it’s store that download videos from YT, so I think it’s fine.
Maybe I’m wrong.

Read full topic

item.title: Youtube downloading & legality
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

I’ve asked a few people about this and some say its legal and some say it’s not.

Obviously the main fact here is that when you visit youtube, the video is being downloaded into your cache. So in theory, downloading the video from the exact same source but storing it in a file you wish to access later is just the same.

However, there is a difference between going on youtube to watch a video and having it innocently stored in your cache than downloading a video specifically so you can save it, convert it to an MP3 and essentially listen to free music.

I can make an application that does all the stuff mentioned above just by inputting a song name, while if I did the same thing on an MP3 sharing site it’d be illegal. It just doesn’t feel right getting free music legally. Or maybe I’m just being a faggot.
